text:
Hi FoodTube! Kerryann here. I'm going to show
you a recipe from Jamie's book, save with

Jamie. It's called Spiced Beef Tagine. It's
a delicious middle eastern inspired dish which

looks really, really posh and the best thing
about it, is that it uses left over beef and

store cupboard essentials. So it's cost effective
and nothing gets wasted! It serves six people

and it comes in around £1.60 per portion.
Who can argue with a bargain like that?! Let's

get started!
The most important part of this recipe for

me is having a really decent casserole pot
with a nice tight fitting lid. What we're

going to do first is roughly chop two red
onions and then two cloves of garlic and we're

going to roughly chop that as well. We've
got 50grams of mixed olives. Now you can see

me struggling to get this tone out. I'm going
to show you a trick that Jamie taught me.

Get the bottom of a cup or a jar and the stone
will pop right out. You don't want to give

it too much of a whack otherwise you'll have
like olive ping pong around the kitchen. I'm

sure the kids would love it, but me not so
much because I have to clean it up. Just run

the knife through them once. We don't want
them too small. Because they'll just disintegrate

and them we've got 75grams dried apricots,
so the same with them. Forget about roast

beef; forget about Yorkshires, we're going
rich and exotic and spicy. Let's get this

lovely casserole pan on the heat, a good lug
of olive oil now it's time to get a little

bit spicy. I've got half a level teaspoon
of dried chilli flakes, they'll go straight

in and two teaspoons of cumin, ground. And
then we've got a heaped teaspoon of garam

masala. A little tip guys there's a special
spice mix that's particularly Moroccan and

it's called Razz Al Hanout. And if you have
any of that in your cupboard. Throw that in.

And it will give you a real authenticity.
Right we're going to leave that to soften

now for about 15mintues. Until it get really
sticky and lovely. And while that's doing.

We're going to chop up our potatoe4s, skin
on. They've been washed so it's fine. So we

want to cut these into two centimetre pieces
and then we're going to roughly chop two ripe

tomatoes as well. We're going to leave things
quite big because it's going to be cooking

for a long time and we don't want to end up
with a pot full of mush.

Now we're going to put in a normal tin of
chickpeas, juice as well. So we don't have

to drain it. What these are going to do now
is soak up all of those spices, all of that

juice, all of those flavours. As they start
cooking they're going to start releasing them

back into the gravy so that's not only going
to make it thick but also really, really tasty.

Here I have some left over roasted brisket.
You can use any other cut of meat. Not a problem.

You can chop this up into bitesizey chunks,
nothing fancy, nothing dramatic. We're going

top put this in the pot 
and give this a good old stir. It's smelling
amazing. Now I'm going to crumble in a beef

stock cube. Just one and them I'm going to
put in 250mls of boiling water, now that's

just under half a pint. Now that's going to
make our gorgeous, gorgeous delicious gravy.

Now a great, great tip if you've got any leftover
gravy, chuck that in. Now believe me that's

like gold. Liquid gold from the heavens above
it's going to add the most beautiful depth

of flavour. We are literally using all of
the leftovers from the roast dinner. We've

got no memory of the roast dinner but we do
have this amazing spicy rich exotic meal that

will make you think of faraway lands and gorgeous
waiters and beautiful beaches. I'm sure you're

there with me. Keep going, keep going.
Right sot hat's boiling now. What we're going

to do is put the lid on, turn it down really
low and leave that to simmer for about 20

to 25mintues. Or until the potatoes are cooked
through.

Let's get started on the couscous and the
salad which are great accompaniments to this

dish. Just cover the couscous with boiling
water and put a plate on top and leave for

10 minutes. Now we're going to make a beautiful
carrot and orange mixed salad. We're going

to go in at an angle and then go in on the
other side. And you're left with a beautiful

segment of orange, not pips, not pith, just
those beautiful capsules of orange juice that

are really refreshing and it looks a bit restaurant.
So two carrots we're going to grate them and

now we're going to pick through some of these
mint leaves. Instead of buying a bunch of

mint, every time you want to use it. Buy a
plant and use it, you can use. Look at that

beautiful juice. Absolutely nothing gets wasted.
We're going to have a little bit of salt and

pepper and some olive oil. Just enough to
dress it. SO pretty!

Now back to the tagine. Look how it's gone
all dark and thick and gorgeous. Nice pinch

of salt and nice pinch of a pepper and a nice
glug of balsamic vinegar.

Now let's get a nice big serving latter because
that's how we like it in my house. Family

style and that's how they do it in Morocco
as well. Everyone eats from the same dish.

SO we've got our couscous. Fluff it up and
season to taste. If you don't fancy couscous

you could use rice or mash potatoes instead.
Kids will love it! Beautiful dark sticky tagine.

Now we're going to sprinkle it with some yoghurt,
relax the spices a bit. Now our refreshing

salad on the top. There you have it my friends.
Spiced beef tagine. And the best thing about

it? It was used from leftovers and store cupboard
ingredients. And for £1.60 per person for

6 people you cannot get a better bargain than
that. Give it a go, let me know how you get

on in the comments box below. Enjoy! And have
a great time! For loads more great recipes

and money saving tips go to jamieoliver.com/savewithjamie.
And for more simple, affordable family videos

on foodtube. Have a look around and subscribe
to get eh latest videos when they're uploaded!.
See ya!
